instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used on the detection of phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms?

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed on the detection of phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms?
Output: Empirical band-ratio algorithms, semianalytical algorithms, and baseline algorithms were employed on the detection of phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance on the detection of phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine-learning models on the detection of phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms is the median error. The median error represents the difference between the predicted values of phycocyanin (PC) obtained from the machine-learning models and the actual PC values measured in the in situ radiometric spectra. 

In terms of accuracy, the study reports that the multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural network model applied to hyperspectral data with a spectral configuration similar to the Hyperspectral Imager for the Coastal Ocean (HICO) achieved median errors of less than 65%. This indicates that the MLP model was able to estimate PC values with a relatively high level of accuracy. 

Furthermore, when the MLP model was applied to resampled data from existing satellite instruments and the proposed band configuration for the next Landsat sensor, the median errors ranged between approximately 73% and 126%. Although these errors are higher compared to the HICO configuration, the results still demonstrate tangible improvements compared to retrievals from multispectral data and benchmark algorithms. 

Overall, the chosen metric of median error provides a quantitative measure of the accuracy of the machine-learning models in estimating PC values, and the results suggest that the MLP model shows promise for developing a globally applicable cyanobacteria measurement approach.

instruction: What other machine-learning models were compared to the multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural network in the study's assessment of the role of spectral resolution in determining phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms?
Output: Support vector regression (SVR), partial least squares regression (PLSR), and XGBoost were compared to the multilayer perceptron (MLP) neural network in the study's assessment of the role of spectral resolution in determining phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms.

instruction: How does the performance of the MLP neural network with hyperspectral data compare to other machine-learning models and benchmark algorithms in detecting phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms?
Output: The performance of the MLP neural network with hyperspectral data is superior to other machine-learning models and benchmark algorithms in detecting phycocyanin pigments in cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms. The MLP neural network applied to the spectral configuration of the Hyperspectral Imager for the Coastal Ocean (HICO) with a full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of < 6 nm achieved median errors of less than 65%. This outperformed other machine-learning models and benchmark algorithms. Additionally, when the MLP model was applied to resampled spectra from existing satellite instruments and the proposed band configuration for the next Landsat sensor, it still delivered tangible improvements compared to retrievals from multispectral data and benchmark algorithms, with median errors ranging from approximately 73% to 126%. These results suggest that employing MLP models with hyperspectral data shows promise for developing a globally applicable approach to measuring cyanobacteria.
